    introduction.Rmd
    library(iwillsurvive)
#> -----------------------------------------------------

library(dplyr)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

    It’s best to start with one-row-per-patient (ORPP) cohort object that contains columns corresponding to

    • patientid, a unique patient identifier
    • index_date, a date corresponding to an index date.
    • censor_date, date corresponding to when patients were censored
    • event_date, date corresponding to the event of interest. NA values indicate that the event was not observed.

    iwillsurvive provides one such example in ez_cohort, a dataframe of 250 simulated patients:

    cohort <- ez_cohort

    derive_*() functions

    Use the derive_*() functions to calculate key derived columns:

    derive_followup_date() returns the column follow_up date, which is event_date (if known), and the censor_date otherwise:

    cohort <- cohort %>%
  derive_followup_date(event_date = "dateofdeath",
                       censor_date = "lastvisitdate")

cohort
#> # A tibble: 250 x 6
#>    patientid condition lotstartdate lastvisitdate dateofdeath followup_date
#>    <chr>     <chr>     <date>       <date>        <date>      <date>       
#>  1 F00001    placebo   2016-05-17   2020-12-01    NA          2020-12-01   
#>  2 F00002    placebo   2020-07-27   2020-08-25    2020-10-05  2020-10-05   
#>  3 F00003    drug      2016-04-14   2017-02-16    2017-03-13  2017-03-13   
#>  4 F00004    drug      2020-06-12   2020-11-25    NA          2020-11-25   
#>  5 F00005    placebo   2019-03-20   2020-01-13    2020-02-21  2020-02-21   
#>  6 F00006    placebo   2017-04-02   2017-10-18    2017-11-19  2017-11-19   
#>  7 F00007    placebo   2018-01-26   2019-01-12    2019-02-17  2019-02-17   
#>  8 F00008    placebo   2015-07-02   2015-11-20    2015-12-23  2015-12-23   
#>  9 F00009    drug      2019-03-08   2020-07-18    2020-08-17  2020-08-17   
#> 10 F00010    placebo   2018-08-23   2019-02-14    2019-03-08  2019-03-08   
#> # … with 240 more rows

    derive_followup_time() returns the columns followup_days, followup_months, and followup_years which show time from index to follow up:

    cohort <- cohort %>%
  derive_followup_time(index_date = "lotstartdate") 

cohort %>%
  select(patientid, lotstartdate, followup_date, 
         followup_days, followup_months, followup_years)
#> # A tibble: 250 x 6
#>    patientid lotstartdate followup_date followup_days followup_months
#>    <chr>     <date>       <date>                <dbl>           <dbl>
#>  1 F00001    2016-05-17   2020-12-01           1660.            54.5 
#>  2 F00002    2020-07-27   2020-10-05             70.1            2.30
#>  3 F00003    2016-04-14   2017-03-13            333.            11.0 
#>  4 F00004    2020-06-12   2020-11-25            167.             5.48
#>  5 F00005    2019-03-20   2020-02-21            338.            11.1 
#>  6 F00006    2017-04-02   2017-11-19            232.             7.61
#>  7 F00007    2018-01-26   2019-02-17            388.            12.7 
#>  8 F00008    2015-07-02   2015-12-23            175.             5.75
#>  9 F00009    2019-03-08   2020-08-17            528.            17.4 
#> 10 F00010    2018-08-23   2019-03-08            197.             6.47
#> # … with 240 more rows, and 1 more variable: followup_years <dbl>

    derive_event_status() will add an event_status column

    cohort <- cohort %>%
  derive_event_status(event_date = "dateofdeath") 

cohort
#> # A tibble: 250 x 10
#>    patientid condition lotstartdate lastvisitdate dateofdeath followup_date
#>    <chr>     <chr>     <date>       <date>        <date>      <date>
